easy.text: Water boils at 100°C at sea level
easy.explanation: Water boils at 100°C (212°F) at sea level atmospheric pressure.

easy.text: The Earth is flat
easy.explanation: The Earth is spherical (oblate spheroid), not flat. This has been proven by centuries of scientific observation.

easy.text: There are 8 planets in our solar system
easy.explanation: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.

easy.text: The sun rises in the west
easy.explanation: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west due to Earth's rotation.

easy.text: Ice is frozen water
easy.explanation: Ice is the solid state of water, formed when water freezes at 0°C (32°F).

easy.text: The moon orbits Earth
easy.explanation: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite and orbits our planet approximately once every 27.3 days.

easy.text: Spiders have 6 legs
easy.explanation: Spiders have 8 legs. Insects have 6 legs.

easy.text: Humans can breathe underwater without equipment
easy.explanation: Humans need oxygen from air to breathe. We cannot extract oxygen from water like fish.

easy.text: A week has 7 days
easy.explanation: A week consists of 7 days: Monday through Sunday.

easy.text: The Great Wall of China is visible from space
easy.explanation: This is a common myth. The Great Wall is not visible from space with the naked eye.

easy.text: Lightning is hotter than the sun's surface
easy.explanation: Lightning can reach temperatures of about 30,000°C, while the sun's surface is about 5,500°C.

easy.text: Gold is heavier than iron
easy.explanation: Gold has a higher density (19.3 g/cm³) than iron (7.87 g/cm³).

easy.text: Bats are blind
easy.explanation: Bats can see, though many species use echolocation as their primary sense.

easy.text: Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth
easy.explanation: Mount Everest is 8,849 meters (29,032 feet) above sea level, making it the tallest mountain.

easy.text: Penguins live at the North Pole
easy.explanation: Penguins live in the Southern Hemisphere, primarily Antarctica. Polar bears live at the North Pole.

easy.text: The capital of France is Paris
easy.explanation: Paris has been the capital of France since the 10th century.

easy.text: The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth
easy.explanation: The Pacific Ocean covers about 30% of Earth's surface.

easy.text: Africa is a country
easy.explanation: Africa is the second-largest continent, containing 54 countries.

easy.text: The Amazon Rainforest is in South America
easy.explanation: Most of the Amazon Rainforest is located in Brazil, with parts in other South American countries.

easy.text: Canada is the largest country in the world by land area
easy.explanation: Russia is the largest country by land area; Canada is second.

easy.text: Elephants are the largest land animals
easy.explanation: African bush elephants are the largest living land mammals.

easy.text: Sharks are mammals
easy.explanation: Sharks are fish; they have gills and are cold-blooded.

easy.text: The human heart has four chambers
easy.explanation: The heart has two atria and two ventricles.

easy.text: Plants produce oxygen
easy.explanation: Plants release oxygen during photosynthesis.

easy.text: Diamonds are made from coal
easy.explanation: Most diamonds form from carbon deep in the Earth's mantle, not from coal.

easy.text: George Washington was the first President of the United States
easy.explanation: He served from 1789 to 1797.

easy.text: The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France
easy.explanation: It was gifted in 1886 to celebrate friendship and democracy.

easy.text: World War I ended in 1918
easy.explanation: The armistice was signed on November 11, 1918.

easy.text: The Titanic sank in 1912
easy.explanation: It hit an iceberg and sank on its maiden voyage.

easy.text: Christopher Columbus discovered America in 1492
easy.explanation: He landed in the Americas in 1492, though indigenous people were already there.

easy.text: The Internet was invented in the 20th century
easy.explanation: Its foundations (like ARPANET) began in the 1960s.

easy.text: Smartphones can take photos
easy.explanation: Most modern smartphones have built-in cameras.

easy.text: The first iPhone was released by Apple
easy.explanation: It was launched in 2007.

easy.text: Computers use electricity to work
easy.explanation: All electronic devices require power, usually electricity.

easy.text: Bluetooth is named after a Viking king
easy.explanation: Named after Harald Bluetooth, who united Danish tribes.

easy.text: There are 12 months in a year
easy.explanation: The Gregorian calendar has 12 months.

easy.text: A leap year has 366 days
easy.explanation: It occurs every 4 years to account for Earth's orbit.

easy.text: The color of the sky is usually blue on a clear day
easy.explanation: Due to Rayleigh scattering of sunlight in the atmosphere.

easy.text: Honey never spoils
easy.explanation: Its low moisture and acidity preserve it indefinitely.

easy.text: There are 24 hours in a day
easy.explanation: A full Earth rotation takes approximately 24 hours.

easy.text: The capital of the United States is Washington, D.C.
easy.explanation: It has been the capital since 1800.

easy.text: Australia is both a country and a continent
easy.explanation: It is the smallest continent and a single nation.

easy.text: The Sahara is the largest desert
easy.explanation: It is the largest hot desert in the world.

easy.text: Japan is an island country
easy.explanation: It consists of over 6,000 islands.

easy.text: The Nile is the longest river in the world
easy.explanation: It measures about 6,650 km long.

easy.text: Birds are descendants of dinosaurs
easy.explanation: Modern birds evolved from theropod dinosaurs.

easy.text: Ostriches can fly
easy.explanation: Ostriches are flightless birds but can run very fast.

easy.text: The human body has 206 bones in adulthood
easy.explanation: Babies have more, but some fuse as they grow.

easy.text: Volcanoes can be active, dormant, or extinct
easy.explanation: These are the three main classifications for volcanoes.

easy.text: Rainbows have 7 colors
easy.explanation: Red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet.

easy.text: The American Civil War ended in 1865
easy.explanation: It concluded with the surrender at Appomattox.

easy.text: Ancient Egyptians built the pyramids
easy.explanation: The Great Pyramids of Giza were built around 2600-2500 BC.

easy.text: The Renaissance began in Italy
easy.explanation: It started in the 14th century in Florence and spread across Europe.

easy.text: Julius Caesar was a Roman emperor
easy.explanation: He was a dictator but never an emperor; Augustus was the first Roman emperor.

easy.text: The Wright brothers invented the airplane
easy.explanation: They achieved the first powered flight in 1903.

easy.text: Wi-Fi uses radio waves
easy.explanation: It transmits data via wireless radio signals.

easy.text: GPS stands for Global Positioning System
easy.explanation: It uses satellites to determine location.

easy.text: The first video game was Pong
easy.explanation: Pong (1972) was popular, but earlier games like Tennis for Two existed.

easy.text: Emails can be sent instantly around the world
easy.explanation: Electronic mail travels via the internet almost instantly.

easy.text: Robots are always human-shaped
easy.explanation: Robots come in many shapes, including industrial arms and vacuums.

easy.text: There are four seasons in a year
easy.explanation: Spring, summer, autumn, winter in most temperate regions.

easy.text: The Olympic Games are held every 4 years
easy.explanation: The Summer and Winter Olympics alternate every 2 years, but each every 4.

easy.text: Chocolate comes from cacao beans
easy.explanation: Cacao pods are processed to make chocolate.

easy.text: Bananas grow on trees
easy.explanation: Bananas grow on large herbaceous plants, not trees.

easy.text: The unicorn is the national animal of Scotland
easy.explanation: It has been a symbol of Scotland since the 12th century.

easy.text: Brazil is in South America
easy.explanation: It is the largest country in South America.

easy.text: The Eiffel Tower is in Paris
easy.explanation: It was built for the 1889 World's Fair.

easy.text: Greenland is the largest island
easy.explanation: Australia is a continent, so Greenland is the largest island.

easy.text: The equator passes through Africa
easy.explanation: It crosses several African countries like Kenya and Uganda.

easy.text: Monaco is the smallest country in the world
easy.explanation: Vatican City is the smallest by area.

easy.text: Butterflies taste with their feet
easy.explanation: They have taste receptors on their legs to detect suitable plants.

easy.text: The sun is a planet
easy.explanation: The sun is a star at the center of our solar system.

easy.text: Sound travels faster than light
easy.explanation: Light travels much faster than sound.

easy.text: Magnets attract all metals
easy.explanation: Magnets attract ferromagnetic metals like iron, not all metals.

easy.text: A tomato is a vegetable
easy.explanation: Botanically, tomatoes are fruits.

easy.text: Neil Armstrong was the first person on the moon
easy.explanation: He stepped on the moon in 1969 during Apollo 11.

easy.text: The Berlin Wall fell in 1989
easy.explanation: It marked the end of the Cold War division of Germany.

easy.text: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch
easy.explanation: She reigned for over 70 years until 2022.

easy.text: The Declaration of Independence was signed in 1776
easy.explanation: It was adopted on July 4, 1776.

easy.text: Alexander the Great was from Greece
easy.explanation: He was king of ancient Macedon, part of Greek culture.

easy.text: Google is a search engine
easy.explanation: It is the most widely used web search engine.

easy.text: Electric cars run on batteries
easy.explanation: They use rechargeable batteries for power.

easy.text: The World Wide Web was invented by Tim Berners-Lee
easy.explanation: He proposed it in 1989.

easy.text: Drones can fly without a pilot on board
easy.explanation: They are unmanned aerial vehicles.

easy.text: Virtual reality headsets create immersive experiences
easy.explanation: They simulate 3D environments for users.

easy.text: Pizza originated in Italy
easy.explanation: Modern pizza developed in Naples in the 18th-19th century.

easy.text: The panda's main food is bamboo
easy.explanation: Giant pandas eat almost exclusively bamboo.

easy.text: Goldfish have a memory span of only 3 seconds
easy.explanation: This is a myth; goldfish can remember things for months.

easy.text: The tallest building in the world is the Burj Khalifa
easy.explanation: It stands in Dubai at over 828 meters.

easy.text: Cricket is a popular sport in England
easy.explanation: It is one of the national sports of England.

easy.text: Italy is shaped like a boot
easy.explanation: Its peninsula resembles a boot kicking Sicily.

easy.text: The Dead Sea is the lowest point on Earth's surface
easy.explanation: It is about 430 meters below sea level.

easy.text: India has the second-largest population
easy.explanation: China is first, India second as of recent years.

easy.text: Mount Kilimanjaro is in Asia
easy.explanation: It is in Tanzania, Africa.

easy.text: The Great Barrier Reef is visible from space
easy.explanation: It is the world's largest coral reef system and can be seen from orbit.

easy.text: Octopuses have eight arms
easy.explanation: They are known for their eight flexible arms.

easy.text: Humans have five senses
easy.explanation: Sight, hearing, taste, smell, and touch are the traditional five.

easy.text: The Earth revolves around the moon
easy.explanation: Earth revolves around the sun; the moon orbits Earth.

easy.text: Flamingos are born pink
easy.explanation: They get their pink color from their diet of shrimp and algae.

easy.text: Gravity keeps us on the ground
easy.explanation: Earth's gravity pulls objects toward its center.

medium.text: The human body has more than 200 bones at birth
medium.explanation: Babies are born with about 270 bones, which fuse together to form 206 bones in adults.

medium.text: The Amazon River is longer than the Nile River
medium.explanation: The Nile River (6,650 km) is slightly longer than the Amazon (6,400 km), though the Amazon carries more water.

medium.text: Sharks are mammals
medium.explanation: Sharks are fish, not mammals. They have gills and are cold-blooded.

medium.text: The speed of light is faster than the speed of sound
medium.explanation: Light travels at 299,792,458 m/s while sound travels at about 343 m/s in air.

medium.text: The Dead Sea is actually a lake
medium.explanation: Despite its name, the Dead Sea is a salt lake bordered by Jordan and Israel.

medium.text: Antarctica is owned by multiple countries
medium.explanation: Antarctica is governed by the Antarctic Treaty System and is not owned by any single nation.

medium.text: Octopuses have three hearts
medium.explanation: Octopuses have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, one pumps blood to the body.

medium.text: The Internet and World Wide Web are the same thing
medium.explanation: The Internet is the infrastructure; the World Wide Web is a service that runs on the Internet.

medium.text: Tomatoes are technically fruits, not vegetables
medium.explanation: Botanically, tomatoes are fruits because they develop from flowers and contain seeds.

medium.text: The first computer programmer was a woman
medium.explanation: Ada Lovelace is considered the first computer programmer for her work in the 1840s.

medium.text: Humans only use 10% of their brain
medium.explanation: This is a myth. Humans use virtually all parts of the brain, and most of it is active most of the time.

medium.text: The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France
medium.explanation: France gave the Statue of Liberty to the United States in 1886 as a gift of friendship.

medium.text: The chemical symbol for gold is Au
medium.explanation: Au comes from the Latin word 'aurum' meaning gold.

medium.text: Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system
medium.explanation: Its thick atmosphere causes a runaway greenhouse effect, reaching temperatures over 460°C.

medium.text: The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest living structure
medium.explanation: It is composed of billions of tiny coral polyps and stretches over 2,300 km.

medium.text: A group of flamingos is called a flock
medium.explanation: A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance'.

medium.text: The human eye can distinguish more shades of green than any other color
medium.explanation: This is due to evolutionary adaptation for spotting food and predators in foliage.

medium.text: Lake Baikal in Russia is the deepest lake in the world
medium.explanation: It reaches a depth of 1,642 meters and holds about 20% of the world's unfrozen freshwater.

medium.text: The capital of Brazil was moved from Rio de Janeiro to Brasília in 1960
medium.explanation: Brasília was purpose-built as the new capital to promote inland development.

medium.text: There are seven continents on Earth
medium.explanation: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia.

medium.text: The Suez Canal connects the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea
medium.explanation: It provides a shortcut between Europe and Asia, avoiding the Cape of Good Hope.

medium.text: Mount Kilimanjaro has three volcanic cones
medium.explanation: Kibo, Mawenzi, and Shira are the three cones, with Kibo being the highest and still dormant.

medium.text: The Magna Carta was signed in 1215
medium.explanation: King John of England agreed to it, establishing principles of limited government.

medium.text: The Industrial Revolution began in France
medium.explanation: It began in Great Britain in the late 18th century.

medium.text: The Battle of Hastings took place in 1066
medium.explanation: William the Conqueror defeated Harold Godwinson, leading to the Norman conquest of England.

medium.text: Joan of Arc was burned at the stake in 1431
medium.explanation: She was executed by the English during the Hundred Years' War.

medium.text: The Rosetta Stone helped decipher Egyptian hieroglyphs
medium.explanation: It contained the same text in Greek, Demotic, and hieroglyphs, providing the key in 1822.

medium.text: The first successful human heart transplant was performed by Christiaan Barnard
medium.explanation: It occurred in 1967 in South Africa.

medium.text: The binary system used in computers consists of only 0s and 1s
medium.explanation: All digital data is represented using binary code.

medium.text: The first commercial web browser was Mosaic
medium.explanation: Released in 1993, it popularized the World Wide Web.

medium.text: A byte consists of 8 bits
medium.explanation: This is the standard unit for digital information storage.

medium.text: The Turing Test evaluates a machine's ability to exhibit human-like intelligence
medium.explanation: Proposed by Alan Turing in 1950.

medium.text: Cloud computing means storing data on physical hard drives
medium.explanation: It refers to storing and accessing data over the internet on remote servers.

medium.text: The first email was sent in 1971
medium.explanation: Ray Tomlinson sent the first networked email on ARPANET.

medium.text: There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all Earth's beaches
medium.explanation: Estimates suggest 10^22 to 10^24 stars vs. about 10^21 grains of sand.

medium.text: French was once the official language of England for over 300 years
medium.explanation: After the Norman Conquest, French was the language of the court until the 14th century.

medium.text: The shortest war in history lasted 38 minutes
medium.explanation: The Anglo-Zanzibar War of 1896 ended after 38-45 minutes.

medium.text: Wombat poop is cube-shaped
medium.explanation: This prevents it from rolling away, helping them mark territory.

medium.text: The unicorn is the national animal of Scotland
medium.explanation: It has symbolized purity and strength since the 12th century.

medium.text: Helium is the second most abundant element in the universe
medium.explanation: Hydrogen is first, helium second, formed during Big Bang nucleosynthesis.

medium.text: A jellyfish is about 95% water
medium.explanation: Their bodies are mostly water with very little solid matter.

medium.text: The speed of sound in water is faster than in air
medium.explanation: Sound travels about 4.3 times faster in water (~1,480 m/s) than in air (~343 m/s).

medium.text: DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid
medium.explanation: It is the molecule that carries genetic instructions in living organisms.

medium.text: The only letter not appearing on the periodic table is J
medium.explanation: All other letters of the alphabet are used in element symbols.

medium.text: The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans
medium.explanation: It allows ships to avoid traveling around South America.

medium.text: Iceland is covered mostly in ice
medium.explanation: Only about 11% is covered by glaciers; Greenland is mostly ice-covered.

medium.text: The longest river entirely within one country is the Yangtze in China
medium.explanation: It stretches over 6,300 km entirely within China.

medium.text: Bhutan measures Gross National Happiness as an official indicator
medium.explanation: It prioritizes happiness and well-being over economic growth alone.

medium.text: The currency of Turkey is the Euro
medium.explanation: Turkey uses the Turkish Lira; it is not part of the Eurozone.

medium.text: The Renaissance began in the 14th century in Italy
medium.explanation: It started in Florence and marked a rebirth of art, science, and learning.

medium.text: The Cold War involved direct military combat between the USA and USSR
medium.explanation: It was a period of geopolitical tension with proxy wars but no direct conflict.

medium.text: The Ottoman Empire lasted over 600 years
medium.explanation: From 1299 to 1922, it was one of the longest-lasting empires.

medium.text: Marie Curie was the first person to win two Nobel Prizes
medium.explanation: She won in Physics (1903) and Chemistry (1911).

medium.text: The first Olympics in modern history were held in Athens in 1896
medium.explanation: Revived by Pierre de Coubertin, they featured 241 athletes from 14 nations.

medium.text: JavaScript and Java are the same programming language
medium.explanation: They are unrelated; JavaScript was created for web browsers, Java for general applications.

medium.text: The first computer 'bug' was an actual insect
medium.explanation: In 1947, Grace Hopper found a moth stuck in a relay of the Harvard Mark II computer.

medium.text: Bitcoin was created by Satoshi Nakamoto
medium.explanation: The pseudonym used in the 2008 whitepaper; the true identity remains unknown.

medium.text: SSL certificates encrypt data transmitted over the internet
medium.explanation: They secure connections, especially for HTTPS websites.

medium.text: The Y2K bug caused widespread global chaos at the turn of the millennium
medium.explanation: Extensive preparation prevented major issues.

medium.text: An octopus can change color to blend into its surroundings
medium.explanation: They use specialized cells called chromatophores for camouflage.

medium.text: The largest organ in the human body is the liver
medium.explanation: The skin is the largest organ by surface area and weight.

medium.text: Photosynthesis primarily occurs in the leaves of plants
medium.explanation: Chloroplasts in leaf cells convert sunlight into energy.

medium.text: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun but not the hottest
medium.explanation: Venus is hotter due to its thick atmosphere.

medium.text: A light-year measures time
medium.explanation: A light-year is a unit of distance, about 9.46 trillion kilometers.

medium.text: The capital of Australia was originally Melbourne
medium.explanation: Melbourne was the temporary capital until Canberra was built in 1927.

medium.text: Liechtenstein has no airport
medium.explanation: The small country relies on nearby Swiss and Austrian airports.

medium.text: The Danube River flows through Vienna, Budapest, Belgrade, and Bucharest
medium.explanation: It passes through four capital cities, more than any other river.

medium.text: The country with the most time zones is France
medium.explanation: Due to its overseas territories, France spans 12 time zones.

medium.text: The Taj Mahal was built by Emperor Shah Jahan as a mausoleum for his wife
medium.explanation: Completed in 1653, it is a masterpiece of Mughal architecture.

medium.text: The Hundred Years' War actually lasted 116 years
medium.explanation: From 1337 to 1453, between England and France.

medium.text: The Incas never developed a writing system
medium.explanation: They used quipus (knotted strings) for record-keeping.

medium.text: The first successful printing press with movable type was invented by Gutenberg
medium.explanation: Around 1440 in Germany, revolutionizing book production.

medium.text: Linux is an open-source operating system
medium.explanation: Created by Linus Torvalds in 1991, its source code is freely available.

medium.text: The domain '.edu' is exclusively for educational institutions
medium.explanation: It is restricted to accredited post-secondary institutions, mostly in the US.

medium.text: Augmented reality overlays digital information on the real world
medium.explanation: Unlike virtual reality, AR enhances rather than replaces the real environment.

medium.text: The first smartphone was the IBM Simon in 1994
medium.explanation: It featured email, fax, and a touchscreen.

medium.text: A group of crows is called a murder
medium.explanation: This collective noun dates back centuries.

medium.text: The term 'byte' was coined by Werner Buchholz
medium.explanation: In 1956 while working on IBM's Stretch computer.

medium.text: The only mammal capable of true flight is the bat
medium.explanation: Other mammals like flying squirrels only glide.

medium.text: Neutrons have no electric charge
medium.explanation: Protons are positive, electrons negative, neutrons neutral.

medium.text: The Amazon rainforest produces about 20% of the world's oxygen
medium.explanation: Often called the 'lungs of the Earth'.

medium.text: There are 195 recognized sovereign countries in the world
medium.explanation: 193 UN member states plus Vatican City and Palestine (UN observer).

medium.text: The Silk Road was a single trade route
medium.explanation: It was a network of routes connecting East and West.

medium.text: VPN stands for Virtual Private Network
medium.explanation: It creates a secure connection over the internet.

medium.text: The human nose can distinguish over 1 trillion different scents
medium.explanation: A 2014 study significantly raised previous estimates.

medium.text: The first person to circumnavigate the globe was Ferdinand Magellan
medium.explanation: Magellan died midway; his crew completed it under Juan Sebastián Elcano.

medium.text: Crocodiles can live over 100 years
medium.explanation: Some species have been documented living beyond a century in captivity.

medium.text: The first website went live in 1991
medium.explanation: Created by Tim Berners-Lee at CERN.

medium.text: The Leaning Tower of Pisa was intentionally built to lean
medium.explanation: It began leaning during construction due to unstable foundation.

medium.text: Ants can lift 50 times their body weight
medium.explanation: Their small size gives them exceptional strength relative to body mass.

medium.text: The currency of Switzerland is the Euro
medium.explanation: Switzerland uses the Swiss Franc.

medium.text: The first successful cloning of a mammal was Dolly the sheep in 1996
medium.explanation: She was cloned from an adult somatic cell.

medium.text: The Great Fire of London in 1666 helped end the plague
medium.explanation: It killed many disease-carrying rats and fleas.

medium.text: OLED screens use organic compounds to emit light
medium.explanation: Unlike LCDs, they don't need a backlight.

medium.text: The shortest complete English word with all five main vowels is 'facetious'
medium.explanation: It contains a, e, i, o, u in order.

medium.text: The human tongue print is unique like a fingerprint
medium.explanation: No two tongue prints are identical.

medium.text: The first space tourist was Dennis Tito in 2001
medium.explanation: He paid $20 million to visit the International Space Station.

medium.text: Quantum computers use qubits instead of traditional bits
medium.explanation: Qubits can exist in superposition, enabling parallel computation.

medium.text: The only country to border both the Caspian Sea and the Persian Gulf is Iran
medium.explanation: Its unique position gives it access to both bodies of water.

medium.text: Octopuses have blue blood
medium.explanation: They use copper-based hemocyanin instead of iron-based hemoglobin.

hard.text: Cleopatra lived closer in time to the Moon landing than to the construction of the Great Pyramid
hard.explanation: The Great Pyramid was built around 2560 BC, Cleopatra lived around 30 BC, and the Moon landing was in 1969 AD.

hard.text: Bananas are berries, but strawberries are not
hard.explanation: Botanically, berries are fruits from a single flower with one ovary. Bananas qualify, strawberries don't.

hard.text: There are more possible iterations of a chess game than atoms in the observable universe
hard.explanation: The Shannon number estimates 10^120 possible chess games, while there are about 10^80 atoms in the universe.

hard.text: Honey never spoils
hard.explanation: Due to its low moisture content and acidic pH, honey can last indefinitely. 3000-year-old honey has been found edible.

hard.text: The human genome contains more genes than a grape
hard.explanation: Humans have about 20,000-25,000 genes, while grapes have about 30,000 genes.

hard.text: Scotland's national animal is a unicorn
hard.explanation: The unicorn has been Scotland's national animal since the 12th century, symbolizing purity and strength.

hard.text: A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus
hard.explanation: Venus takes 243 Earth days to rotate once (a day) but only 225 Earth days to orbit the Sun (a year).

hard.text: The fingerprints of koalas are virtually indistinguishable from human fingerprints
hard.explanation: Koala fingerprints are so similar to human ones that they could theoretically contaminate crime scenes.

hard.text: The Eiffel Tower can be 15 cm taller during summer
hard.explanation: Due to thermal expansion, the iron structure expands in heat, making the tower slightly taller.

hard.text: Oxford University is older than the Aztec Empire
hard.explanation: Oxford University started teaching in 1096, while the Aztec Empire began in 1428.

hard.text: There are more trees on Earth than there are stars in the Milky Way galaxy
hard.explanation: Estimates suggest about 3 trillion trees on Earth vs. 100-400 billion stars in the Milky Way.

hard.text: A flock of crows is known as a murder, but a group of ravens is called an unkindness or a conspiracy
hard.explanation: These are the traditional collective nouns for ravens.

hard.text: The only letter that does not appear in any U.S. state name is Q
hard.explanation: No U.S. state name contains the letter Q.

hard.text: France has more time zones than any other country
hard.explanation: Due to its overseas territories, France spans 12 time zones.

hard.text: The unicorn became Scotland's national animal because King James VI believed it was the natural enemy of the lion (England's symbol)
hard.explanation: The mythical rivalry was used to symbolize opposition to England.

hard.text: Octopuses have nine brains
hard.explanation: One central brain and one small brain in each of the eight arms.

hard.text: The first oranges were not orange
hard.explanation: Original oranges from Southeast Asia were green; the orange color developed in cooler climates.

hard.text: There is enough gold in Earth's core to cover the entire surface of the planet in a layer 4 meters thick
hard.explanation: Estimates suggest about 0.5 meters thick at most; the statement is exaggerated.

hard.text: The shortest war in history was between Britain and Zanzibar and lasted 38 minutes
hard.explanation: On August 27, 1896, Zanzibar surrendered after 38-45 minutes of naval bombardment.

hard.text: Nintendo was founded before the fall of the Ottoman Empire
hard.explanation: Nintendo was founded in 1889; the Ottoman Empire ended in 1922.

hard.text: The first computer virus was created in 1983 and called Elk Cloner
hard.explanation: Elk Cloner (1982) was early, but Creeper (1971) is considered the first virus.

hard.text: A 'jiffy' is an actual unit of time: 1/100th of a second
hard.explanation: In computing, a jiffy varies; in physics, it's sometimes the time light takes to travel one centimeter (~33 ps).

hard.text: The Great Wall of China is the only man-made structure visible from the Moon
hard.explanation: No man-made structures are visible from the Moon with the naked eye; this is a persistent myth.

hard.text: The Canary Islands are named after dogs, not birds
hard.explanation: From Latin 'Insula Canaria' meaning 'Island of Dogs', referring to large dogs found there.

hard.text: Harvard University was founded before calculus was invented
hard.explanation: Harvard founded in 1636; Newton and Leibniz developed calculus in the late 17th century.

hard.text: The longest fence in the world is Australia's Dingo Fence
hard.explanation: It stretches over 5,600 km to keep dingoes away from fertile land.

hard.text: Sharks have been around longer than trees
hard.explanation: Sharks appeared ~450 million years ago; trees ~385 million years ago.

hard.text: The first emails were sent before the invention of the telephone
hard.explanation: Telephone 1876; first networked email 1971.

hard.text: More people have walked on the Moon than have been to the deepest point in the ocean
hard.explanation: 12 moonwalkers vs. only 3 people (repeated visits) to Challenger Deep.

hard.text: The Hundred Years' War lasted exactly 100 years
hard.explanation: It lasted 116 years (1337–1453).

hard.text: The only South American country to have English as an official language is Guyana
hard.explanation: Guyana's colonial history with Britain makes English its official language.

hard.text: A 'pangram' is a sentence that uses every letter of the alphabet at least once
hard.explanation: Example: 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog'.

hard.text: The first domain name ever registered was symbolics.com in 1985
hard.explanation: It was the first .com domain registered on March 15, 1985.

hard.text: There are more public libraries in the U.S. than McDonald's restaurants
hard.explanation: ~16,000 public libraries vs. ~14,000 McDonald's.

hard.text: The first product with a barcode scanned at a checkout was a pack of Wrigley's gum
hard.explanation: Scanned on June 26, 1974, in Troy, Ohio.

hard.text: The Amazon rainforest produces more oxygen than all other forests combined
hard.explanation: It produces ~20%; oceans and other forests contribute significantly more overall.

hard.text: The country of Liberia was founded by freed American slaves
hard.explanation: Founded in 1822 by the American Colonization Society for freed slaves.

hard.text: The first animated feature film was made in Argentina in 1917
hard.explanation: El Apóstol by Quirino Cristiani, predating Disney's Snow White.

hard.text: The probability of a coin landing on its edge is approximately 1 in 6000
hard.explanation: Depends on thickness and spin, but studies show roughly that ratio.

hard.text: Anne Frank's diary was first published in English before Dutch
hard.explanation: Published in Dutch in 1947 as 'Het Achterhuis', English in 1952.

hard.text: The first country to grant women the right to vote was New Zealand in 1893
hard.explanation: New Zealand was the first self-governing country to grant all women the vote.

hard.text: The longest river in the world by water volume is the Amazon
hard.explanation: It discharges far more water than the Nile, though slightly shorter in length.

hard.text: The first programmer in history wrote an algorithm for a machine that was never built
hard.explanation: Ada Lovelace wrote notes on Babbage's Analytical Engine in 1843.

hard.text: The word 'robot' comes from a Czech word meaning 'forced labor'
hard.explanation: From Karel Čapek's 1920 play R.U.R., derived from 'robota'.

hard.text: There are more atoms in a glass of water than glasses of water in all the oceans
hard.explanation: Avogadro's number (~10^23) vs. estimated ~10^21 glasses in oceans.

hard.text: The first YouTube video was uploaded in 2005 and titled 'Me at the zoo'
hard.explanation: Uploaded by co-founder Jawed Karim on April 23, 2005.

hard.text: The only planet named after a Greek god rather than a Roman one is Uranus
hard.explanation: Most planets use Roman names; Uranus uses the Greek Ouranos.

hard.text: The first successful vaccine was for smallpox, developed by Edward Jenner in 1796
hard.explanation: He used cowpox material to create immunity.

hard.text: The longest place name in the world is in New Zealand and has 85 letters
hard.explanation: Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu.

hard.text: The first person to reach the North Pole was Robert Peary in 1909
hard.explanation: His claim is disputed; many believe no one reached it until 1948 or later verified expeditions.

hard.text: The human body contains enough iron to make a small nail
hard.explanation: ~4 grams of iron, enough for a ~3-inch nail.

hard.text: The first photograph of a person was taken in 1838 in Paris
hard.explanation: Louis Daguerre's boulevard photo with a man getting his shoes shined (long exposure).

hard.text: The only continent without reptiles is Antarctica
hard.explanation: Extreme cold prevents reptiles from surviving.

hard.text: The first computer mouse was made of wood
hard.explanation: Douglas Engelbart's 1964 prototype was wooden.

hard.text: The original name for Pac-Man was Puck-Man
hard.explanation: Changed for U.S. release to avoid vandalism altering 'P' to 'F'.

hard.text: The first country to use postcards was Austria in 1869
hard.explanation: The 'Correspondenz-Karte' was introduced there.

hard.text: The loudest animal relative to its size is the pistol shrimp
hard.explanation: Its claw snap creates a cavitation bubble reaching 218 dB.

hard.text: The first novel ever written was 'The Tale of Genji' by Murasaki Shikibu around 1010 AD
hard.explanation: Considered the world's first novel, written in Japan.

hard.text: The only letter not used in the periodic table element symbols is J
hard.explanation: All other letters appear at least once.

hard.text: The first search engine was called Archie, created in 1990
hard.explanation: It indexed FTP archives before the web existed widely.

hard.text: The shortest place name in the world is 'Å' in Norway and Sweden
hard.explanation: Several villages named Å exist.

hard.text: The first alarm clock could only ring at 4 AM
hard.explanation: Invented by Levi Hutchins in 1787 for his own wake-up time.

hard.text: The first recorded use of 'OMG' was in a 1917 letter to Winston Churchill
hard.explanation: Admiral John Fisher used it in correspondence.

hard.text: The first known contraceptive was used in ancient Egypt around 1850 BC
hard.explanation: Crocodile dung mixed with honey as a pessary.

hard.text: The only sea without a land boundary is the Sargasso Sea
hard.explanation: Defined by ocean currents in the Atlantic.

hard.text: The first website was dedicated to explaining the World Wide Web project itself
hard.explanation: Tim Berners-Lee's site at info.cern.ch in 1991.

hard.text: The longest time between two twins being born is 87 days
hard.explanation: Recorded in 2012 due to premature birth of one twin.

hard.text: The first coins were minted in Lydia (modern Turkey) around 600 BC
hard.explanation: Made of electrum, a gold-silver alloy.

hard.text: The only bird that can fly backwards is the hummingbird
hard.explanation: Its wing structure allows unique maneuverability.

hard.text: The first book ever printed with movable type was the Gutenberg Bible in 1455
hard.explanation: Johannes Gutenberg's masterpiece.

hard.text: The country with the most pyramids is Sudan, not Egypt
hard.explanation: Sudan has over 250 Nubian pyramids vs. Egypt's ~120.

hard.text: The first floppy disk was 8 inches in diameter
hard.explanation: Introduced by IBM in 1971.

hard.text: The only English word with five consecutive vowels is 'queueing'
hard.explanation: u-e-u-e-i-n-g has five vowels in a row.

hard.text: The first canned food was developed for Napoleon's army
hard.explanation: Nicolas Appert won a prize in 1810 for preservation method.

hard.text: The only element named after a living person at the time of naming is Seaborgium (Sg)
hard.explanation: Named after Glenn Seaborg while he was still alive.

hard.text: The first recorded Olympic marathon winner was disqualified for cheating
hard.explanation: Spiridon Louis won fairly in 1896; Fred Lorz was disqualified in 1904.

hard.text: The longest national anthem by lyrics is Greece's, with 158 stanzas
hard.explanation: Hymn to Liberty; only first two stanzas are usually sung.

hard.text: The first person convicted by DNA evidence was in 1987 in the UK
hard.explanation: Colin Pitchfork was convicted of murder using DNA fingerprinting.

hard.text: The only U.S. president to hold a patent was Abraham Lincoln
hard.explanation: Patent for a device to lift boats over shoals.

hard.text: The first touchscreen phone was IBM's Simon in 1994
hard.explanation: It included email and fax capabilities.

hard.text: The only moon in the solar system with a thick atmosphere is Titan
hard.explanation: Thicker than Earth's, mostly nitrogen.

hard.text: The first country to abolish slavery was Haiti in 1804
hard.explanation: Following its revolution against France.

hard.text: The only number whose letters are in alphabetical order is 'forty'
hard.explanation: F-o-r-t-y is strictly alphabetical.

hard.text: The first electric traffic light was installed in Cleveland in 1914
hard.explanation: Red and green lights with buzzers.

hard.text: The only mammal that can truly fly is the bat
hard.explanation: Others like flying squirrels only glide.

hard.text: The first human heart transplant patient survived for 18 days
hard.explanation: Louis Washkansky in 1967 by Christiaan Barnard.

hard.text: The only African country never colonized is Ethiopia
hard.explanation: Resisted Italian attempts; Liberia was founded by freed slaves.

hard.text: The first CD pressed in the U.S. was Bruce Springsteen's 'Born in the U.S.A.'
hard.explanation: At the first U.S. CD plant in 1984.

hard.text: The only prime number that is even is 2
hard.explanation: All other even numbers are divisible by 2.

hard.text: The first roller coaster was built in Russia in the 17th century
hard.explanation: Ice slides with wheeled sleds in St. Petersburg.

hard.text: The only country to have a non-rectangular flag is Nepal
hard.explanation: Two stacked pennants.

hard.text: The first CAPTCHA was created to digitize books
hard.explanation: Luis von Ahn's reCAPTCHA helped scan old texts.

hard.text: The only word in English with three consecutive double letters is 'bookkeeper'
hard.explanation: oo-kk-ee.

hard.text: The first nuclear-powered submarine was USS Nautilus in 1954
hard.explanation: It famously went 'under the North Pole' in 1958.

hard.text: The only metal that is liquid at room temperature is mercury
hard.explanation: Others like gallium melt just above.

hard.text: The first woman in space was Valentina Tereshkova in 1963
hard.explanation: She orbited Earth 48 times on Vostok 6.

hard.text: The only U.S. state whose name is one syllable is Maine
hard.explanation: All others have at least two syllables.

hard.text: The first video uploaded to YouTube lasts 18 seconds
hard.explanation: 'Me at the zoo' shows Jawed Karim at San Diego Zoo.

hard.text: The only number spelled with letters in alphabetical order is 'forty'
hard.explanation: No other number has letters strictly in order.

hard.text: The first successful human-to-human blood transfusion was performed in 1818 by James Blundell
hard.explanation: He treated postpartum hemorrhage.
